awd_titl_txt: Standard: Collaborative Research: Changing Ethical STEM Culture through Interdisciplinary Dialogue and Analysis of Humanitarian Information and Communication Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The humanitarian sector has been engaged in ethical STEM activities for many decades since success in humanitarian practice is based on the ability to deliver aid according to moral and ethical principles. Humanitarian STEM work can thus expose tensions between the ethical imperatives of humanitarian missions (e.g., accountability to those being assisted), and the typical goals of STEM design, development, and use (e.g., efficiency). This project examines the implementation of STEM within a humanitarian environment to offer new understandings, priorities, and directions for changing ethical cultures within the broader STEM arena. It will focus on understanding how humanitarian ethical imperatives are addressed in the design, development, and implementation of STEM, and how understanding of these processes can be translated into frameworks for successfully achieving more ethically-centered STEM cultures. To do so, the Red Cross Global Disaster Preparedness Center will partner with University of Washington to systematically evaluate the Red Cross's efforts to design and develop STEM in alignment with humanitarian ethical imperatives. This human-centered approach will integrate perspectives from practitioners, STEM experts, and aid beneficiaries to reveal practical challenges and solutions for achieving more ethical STEM cultures. This research will provide data and information for improving how STEM technologies can be integrated into humanitarian work in a more ethical manner, and for cultivating more ethical STEM cultures.

This project examines how STEM information and communications technologies have been implemented in humanitarian working environments. The goal is to enhance understanding of how humanitarian ethics can be built into the design, development, and implementation of ICTs, and how lessons learned from case studies involving the Red Cross can be used to develop new frameworks for cultivating more ethically-centered STEM cultures.  This will be accomplished through analyses of case studies where humanitarian ICT projects have been used to support Red Cross humanitarian work through a combination of literature reviews, secondary data analysis, and interviews with relevant stakeholders across the design, development, and implementation process. Phase 1 involves collecting secondary data, identifying case studies, and developing research instruments. Phase 2 involves analyzing the case studies. Phase 3 involves assembling a practitioner-academic consortium, sharing findings, and facilitating dialogue at Red Cross Global Disaster Preparedness Center workshops to create practical recommendations for ethical design of Humanitarian information and communications technologies. Phases 4 and 5 involve preparing ethically-centered STEM solutions, taking lessons to the humanitarian and academic communities for application and assessment, and disseminating project findings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Robin E. Mays, in partnership with the Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC) of the American Red Cross led by Omar Abou-Samra, and the Univ. of Washington Center for Collaborative Systems for Safety, Security and Regional Resilience Lab at the Dept of Human-Centered Design & Engineering led by Prof. Mark Haselkorn, conducted a study of how moral work requirements are negotiated when creating humanitarian technologies. The results reveal new interdisciplinary understanding, thinking, and solutions for shifting the culture of technology creation. We assert that STEM ethical culture must be addressed within the core work of the science, itself.  We introduce accountability to humanitarian outcomes of humanitarian technology by integrating approaches and assessments of core humanitarian work as concrete and leading components of computer science (CS) design, development, and implementation. These results identify new ways for incorporating greater social accountability culture into STEM practice, research and education overall.

This research offers its most immediate impact through its influence on how the Red Cross Red Crescent Societies (RCRC) approach the development and design of humanitarian technologies.  Our research reveals a root mismatch between the quality evaluations for the technical work of computer engineering versus that of humanitarian work. Yet, effective humanitarian technologies need to meet the standards of both. Whereas CS core-work of good digital engineering & design is assessed according to engineering standards, humanitarians? core-work of good humanitarian outcomes is assessed according to various humanitarian standards. Humanitarian effectiveness is predicated, first and foremost, upon accountability to the communities they serve. While it is imperative for tech to adhere to quality standards for both domains to be effective, they have not routinely been assessed for the latter. Filling the gap in assessment for humanitarian accountability of tech offers the possibility to bring a greater ratio of more useful and sustainable tech solutions within the humanitarian space.

Specifically, this work shifts technology design, development, and deployment processes from an approach where tech is viewed as a commodity to be purchased, to an approach where tech partners are recognized as agents of social change requiring a more mutual and shared understanding, and accounting. This approach prioritizes product assessment for adherence to humanitarian accountability and effectiveness social requirements. Our results cultivate far-reaching benefits for RCRC global humanitarian practice to bring better humanitarian outcomes and serves as a model for the important global work of the broader humanitarian community to improve the resiliency of vulnerable populations facing crises. 

Further, this joint interdisciplinary work enhances an understanding for integrating social needs of moral types of work into future research and education. Our practice-academia collaboration has generated new practice-driven learning across disciplines and fields of knowledge, and created opportunities to take this learning directly to students, researchers and practitioners. 

A targeted Research Agenda for Socio-Accountable Tech brings specific challenges to the socio-technical field to expand methods to integrate social accountability requirements into the iteration and assessment of digital products. It offers new lines of research to address the methods/tools gap for accommodating socially or morally accountablework. Longer term joint research and learning priorities for humanitarian accountability in tech include exploring:  

  • Future methodological areas for accommodating a) information relevancy, b) multi-directional pathways for dynamic meaning and c) trusted and agentic social networks
  • The creation of development and design tools and processes for assessing humanitarian accountability for conducting a holistic socio-technical systems iteration.
  • Plain language coding, tools and processes for providing transparency of digital development and design options for the purpose of community-owned assessment and decision-making.

Finally, these intellectual contributions are not only humanitarian in nature.  Social Accountability for tech and how it is achieved is a need that transcends beyond humanitarian work and has the potential to improve digital and data support to all types of social governance and community agency work to include: education, health, and other social governance models. Expanding STEM?s perspective and ability to accommodate social norms broadly expands the ethical culture of STEM at the level of the core work. From protecting the individual right to self-determination to more effective delivery of the range of social services, a future interdisciplinary agenda will support STEM that not only makes lives easier but also shepherds greater social care, well-being, agency, equity and resilience. Through the opening of new lines of practice and education for making CS more accountable to the social good, we increase the well-being of our communities.

Building upon decades of humanitarian operational learning and socio-technological advances, we have expanded general understanding of how and why to accommodate social accountability into technology development.  The outcomes of this project will have immediate application to the shared struggle to apply STEM to make humanitarian work more effective and to increase the ability to reduce suffering and make lives more resilient.
